This is by far my favorite episode.

A few thoughts:

Though sending messages into space in the hopes of reaching extraterrestrials and starting further communication may be secondary to the thought experiment about what it is that we would like to communicate about ourselves and how we would communicate and although humanity has emitted signals into space since well before we were aware of what we were doing, it’s true that in human history, civilizations, people groups, and empires that have encountered an “other” who lacks equivalent technological advancements have treated those without the same level of advancement horrifically a majority of the time and en masse. Unfortunately, that does not speak well of humanity, at least yet. We are still writing our own story and we cannot change the past, but we can show our capacity for reform and change the narrative.

I also want to acknowledge that though the experiment run with Steve Vance from JPL and the experts in various fields was interesting and is probably about the best means of experiment we could realistically run at this time, I am not convinced that people or other beings encountering a message that is randomized would not attempt to read some meaning into it OR that a message that humans send to space would not be misinterpreted or have meanings added to it if another group of beings were to run across it.

I don’t know that this is not dangerous but given that we have already sent out messages for a reasonable amount of time and given the scale of the universe and how relatively short of a distance those messages have gone as compared to the size of the observable universe, unless we horribly misunderstand the limitations of transportation speed through space (this is not impossible), it would still take any other being living near another star in inordinately long amount of time to travel here given that they are able to reach the greatest known speed possible to travel through space.

This episode raised a ton of questions about what it means to be human and alive on this planet, in our tiny corner of the universe. I hope that thinking about these things and just how small we are in the scheme of things helps us to put our petty qualms with each other aside and to think with humanity’s legacy and our story and how we would like it to be in mind.

The problem with the arguments against sending messages into space is that any race advanced enough to not only intercept the message but also to travel to Earth from wherever they are is already going to have the technology to know that there are planets in this system. If they're not exploiting it already it's because they don't care to. The only way that them knowing the planet had life on it would lead to an invasion would be if they were religious zealots or if their advanced civilization really needed lumber for some reason, because converts and lumber are the only two things they couldn't get elsewhere. The sort of incidents that Hawking and so forth were talking about didn't happen because of the presence of a weaker civilization, but despite it; the Spanish empire for example didn't care about the mesoamericans one way or the other, they just wanted the gold

comment_text: Here's a suggestion on how to show benevolence in a ship-to-ship first contact scenario; use a robotic arm to wave, then reach behind your craft (into a storage bay) to grab a chunk of gold, then, in a slower motion, move it to between you, and VERY slowly push it towards the other craft. this will indicate your average speed of movement, and how the moving of gold towards the alien is in a speed much slower than your usual, implying caution and hopefully not violence. Whether the aliens are made of circutry or microscopic chemical stroctures, radiation likely messes them up quite badly, so cautiously gifting them a material that is VERY good at making circutry AND blocking radiation, is highly malleable, and rare even in space, but not too rare for them to have found, is almost guaranteed to be giving them something beneficial, and therefore is highly likely to be seen as a sign of goodwill.

The problem with the experiment is that it was randomized. Certainly, humans do not intend to ever send a completely random message into space. The message will inherently contain patterns and geometry. If the goal was to prove aliens may  "read into" patterns then patterns should have been randomly distributed in the message. It's like Jason said, "even symmetry would have been a big thing for me." Human brains are optimized for pattern recognition. Put another way, they're optimized to seek patterns. It is called Pareidolia.  It is when we humans impose a meaning in random information. Such as seeing the  shape of an animal in a cloud. Although the cloud's shape is completely random, the fact that the cloud's shape roughly matches the shape of an animal the database in our brain has seen before, is why meaning is assigned (ie. it resembles something we know). I think the experiment needs to be redone to draw any kind of real world conclusions. In the second experiment, random symmetries should be included in the message. Or even geometric block shapes randomly distributed in the message. If the experiment was executed in this way, I think you'd find that your hypothesis would be proven true.

you know i find it funny how people are so set on rigid ideas. like i’m a math student and a science nerd but i have never trusted the maths and laws of earth when it comes to outer space. i genuinely believe we, as humans, cannot comprehend the truth. im not saying i have any ideas about space, i’ve got no f*cking clue😂 but i don’t think that just because there is a high probability of aliens existing given the huge expanse of space, that intelligent life forms do exist. like theoretically because there is a chance they exist, then theoretically they do exist, as space is ever growing however many years away/ahead/behind it will happen somewhere. i’m all for looking for aliens because it would be stupid not to. the only way you’d ever be able to confirm that aliens do or don’t exist is by finding one. which essentially means if there are none it will never be confirmed because the only way to confirm that is to search all of space (impossible) or find an alien, but finding an alien confirms their existence, not their absence. idk i think that things like this are so far beyond our understanding, like space being an ever growing vacuum that grows “into” nothing. it’s near impossible to imagine that space isn’t expanding into something. say you blow up a balloon. it expands into space that was already there, whereas space doesn’t have an edge or a limit, one moment space is *insert area* and the next it has formulated a whole new part of space that never existed. i find it easier to think of space expanding into nothing like when you close one eye and just see nothing. like you don’t see anything. close both eyes and you see your eyelids but close one and you can’t see anything from that eye, it’s like that space has left, it doesn’t exist. that’s hard to comprehend because we always assume “nothing” is visible. if someone takes out your eyes, there is now just nothing, but your brain cannot imagine that unless you literally have no eyes or are 100% blind.
also to confirm: i do trust science and maths, im just very open minded and i’m also not set on space expanding but i accept that as the truth for now. i also think just because there is a chance aliens exist, doesn’t mean they do. the universe is incredible and it reminds me of a dystopian novel where you have to find the clues to work out what’s going on. like there are no coincidences about earths nature, yet it is predictable and you will always find patterns in it. but i don’t know that applying earth’s logic to anywhere else but earth is a sensible idea. gravity here for example is completely different, likewise the laws of science will also be completely different here than in space. like if i drew a line without you looking and covered part of it with my finger, there is a very high probability that under my finger is a straight line connecting the two either side of my finger, but there is also the possibility that right where i put my finger there are a bunch of scribbles connecting the lines. idk i guess im just saying ... actually i don’t know what im saying at this point, oh well **insert relevant conclusion**. Alternative possible answers to the Fermi Paradox.

1. We’re boring.
2. Most sentients stay in the Paleolithic Paradise and never invent space travel.
3. They have ethical restraints against messing with baby civilizations.
4. We’re too dumb to realize that they’re communicating with us.
5. We’re too aggressive for them to risk it.
6. They’ve studied us and just don’t like us.
7. They’re already in contact with the fungal network, which they consider the real intelligent life force on Earth.

6:18 this guy is supposed to be an expert. That's either a lie or a mistake or he's actually clueless. "Every civilization that can travel between the stars, have already picked up I Love Lucy." That's not true at all! Ignoring the obvious I'll point out your walkie talkies don't even work further than three blocks apart. Your local television station stops making it to your TV within a few hundred miles broadcasted on the air waves. Some radio frequencies can bounce off the ionosphere and you can catch a signal just beyond the horizon. But your ham radio isn't sending Star trek re-runs to epsilon Perseii 8 and the aliens that live there. It's takes the largest few radio telescopes/transmitters available on Earth to successfully continue communicating with the Voyagers.your football field size array might not cut it. And they aren't even 1 light year away. They're still light hours away. A space faring civilization 65 million LY away would see dinosaurs if they look at earth right now. Even if they could pick up the i love Lucy reruns they wouldn't receive them for another 65 million years. 1 million LY away look at earth right now you might find some common chimp ancestor or some other hominids. 150 LY away and they'd have no idea we developed electricity or airplanes or cars or radios. That's no excuse to be flashing your high beams at them right now though. Might have gone unnoticed before but not when you shine a laser beam in their eyeballs. Figuratively speaking.

There is no such thing as settled science. Michael you even said it yourself the half life of knowledge is arguably about five years. Barely 50 years ago we didn't even know red dwarf stars exist at all. Today we think we know the closest stat to the Sun IS a red dwarf. Like oh we've only been missing the closest star to the sun AALLLL THIS TIIIIME. The same flaw presents itself when people of EVERY caliber think they know climate change. We barely have a grasp on the laws of nature as it is. Only fools think they know it all.  For all we know that red dwarf proxima centauri is actually a cloaked Dyson sphere rocketing toward earth by hitching a ride with alpha centauri which is partially responsible for it's cloaking. 99.9~% would say heck no it's not. But how do YOOOOU actually KNOOOOW? Because somebody told you what to believe? Oh it's because you've been there. I stand corrected. My point is every 50-80 years or so somebody pops into the forefront of science and flips the table erases the chalkboards and rips up a handful of PhDs and says "look. This is how things REALLY work." And the entire scientific consensus practically overnight goes "oooooOOOOHHHHH!!" and adopts it. We're about due for another round of. Some new Einstein is lurking on the internet being mocked by many of you and shut down for their blasphemous words contradicting what you think you know. If Isaac Newton was on Twitter today, he be banned already. Welcome to the great technological stagnation of the 21st century. Blame it all on covid if ya want. After all, archeologists eons from now will uncover this sedimentary layer and say "see all these petrified face masks? That's the 2020 marker. Let's keep digging..

I've not yet watched but I know things so here I am.

Alot of work went into this video and I'm sure I will thoroughly enjoy it but my PBS-education has taught me that the answer to "are we alone" is "unlikely but space is big".

The reason we have not seen evidence of intelligent life beyond earth is due to scale. Universe is big and habitable planets are few.

We've also only been tracking space radiation for a little over a hundred years. A very brief time in the grand-scale of space.

Let's say the nearest civilization is 10k light-years away. Let's also say that they began to broadcast into space 5k years ago. Humans will likely be extinct before that broadcast reaches us.

The reason some scholars are dubious is because they're working on the assumption that we are late bloomers. If equivalent civilizations were abundant 50k years ago then we would likely have seen some evidence of it.

That leads into the theory that most civilizations destroy themselves (in one way or another) before becoming a significant influence to spacial readings. This theory sucks and I'll have no part it! (STAR TREK IS REAL DAMNIT)

I'm sure their video covered all of this, and then some, but showing that I know more than at least one of you is all that my small and fragile ego requires. This comment shall sustain me until I can find a 12-year-old to correct.

You should assess the "should we" with probability. Even simple two axis consideration, are they likely to be less, equal or more powerful than us, and are they likely to be altruistic or not? I understand the scientific consensus is that they are likely to be more powerful (due to universe's age) and not altruistic, considering our observation of earth species. Cross-species altruism is a rare sight. How many animals avoid stepping on ants? So even if the aliens are not expansionist, driven by motives of greed, paranoia, or aggression, it could be just practical, economical reason, we, or our planet could be seen as commodity, a raw material for something greater, and our intelligent not high enough, for them to care about us.

So, lots of "nope" from me.

Also the 6:00 argument, we are already transmitting, we should just transmit more is really weak, and should just make us work harder to not transmit intentionally. Two wrongs don't make a right.

comment_text: I think it's probable that an advanced space capable civilization will have progressed beyond colonial type relations. That has been the history of people as we better learn how to function as a society. Family, tribe, city, state, nation, confederacy of states and eventually a united earth. If you want to see a better example of this experiment you could look at the 2016 introduction of Sombra, the world class hacker.  Because of her background an online community went looking for cryptic clues from messages, codes within web pages and even in hidden video frames - I can't describe it properly but a group of talented code breakers spent many more hours than these guys working on the case.  At one point they found in the sky on one of the images a certain circular pattern that they found by increasing the contrast.  It became an endeavor several orders of magnitude greater than compared to the effort in this video.  It happened in real world time as there was a perceived deadline and they wanted to crack the code hidden by Sombra before the time was up.  To have seen the posts and videos as it happened, it was "an event sociological."  Worthy someday of a movie.  What is an ARG?  It is an Alternate Reality Game where effort extends from game space and spills out into the real world, to find clues at that time about the mystery of Sombra.  You can still find the story, fascinating reading by searching for "the Sombra sky code" ...you may see how deep this rabbit hole goes.

If an alien received our messages right now, at 100 light-years away, the answer would take another 100 years to be received. And due the fact Earth and Solar System move around space, it would be impossible to answer a message since the place where it was sent is not the same where it will be received. The may have answered all our messages but Earth was not there to receive the call. No paradox in there.
And if they could detect the source of a message, they would track it as being the Sun, not the Earth, since Earth is invisible from such a distance. And except in the exact point where Earth is between the Sun and the source of the reply in the exact moment of its arrival, we wouldn't even know it was sent. Again, no paradox.

While I don't think that we are alone in the universe our galaxy may be a different story. For example, putting the universe on a 2D plane, with the origin as the start point, if where north, and another galaxy is traveling south, if both are traveling faster than or at half the speed of light, it is in terms of distance the same as saying galaxy us, is moving at lightspeed, + x while galaxy A, is stationary at origin.

Long story short it is impossible for our transmissions to reach galaxy A without causing them to go faster than light, and then, is also the issue of time taken to close the gap.

We can assume that our waves will hit every corner of our own galaxy eventually however. If it takes 100 years for our transmissions to get to alien A, it will if alien A's advanced as us take another 100 years to reply.

I don't necessarily believe faster than light travel is quite "required" for same galaxy traversion either. Meaning even meeting an alien invasion or friendly contact anytime soon is fairly unlikely. Especially considering the radii of the sphere drawn by our earliest waves that we did transmit. I don't believe that it covers even 1% of the galaxy yet as it is. But lets say that 1% would be equivalent to 100 lightyear radii, having a reply isn't ideal for a few reasons

Sometimes I wonder about people, they have COMPUTER programmers in the room, and they're listening to the tones coming FROM A COMPUTER, and transcribing them on a PAD of PAPER. Seriously, what is wrong with this picture....ANYONE????

Also, I haven't watched the whole thing yet, but JUST giving them supposed noise is only half the problem, you should also given them real messages, designed carefully, like the Arecibo pic, and see if they can garner the right info from an intended message. In fact, I would have done that first.

If you had people in there that were REALLY SERIOUSLY DANGEROUSLY smart, they may have returned with the number generator and seed, if you used such a method. ;-) The aliens could NEVER have the remotest chance of doing that, for obvious reasons, NOTHING in common except the physics they both observe. All of this is really kind of silly to my mind though, when you can't tell a story to the person beside you in a twenty person circle and have it come back around to the originator as anything recognizable, usually.

Then there are data points like the WWII 'code talkers' using an obscure archaic Native American language (IIRC) as code for military communication transmissions that was never broken....what possible chance is another COMPLETELY alien civilization that has had no contact with ours going to have to decipher anything we send as remotely correct? Pretty much none, that's what. I WILL give them serious points on figuring out the prime number thing....but AGAIN, that is something that is common to some of the schemes used for that type of transmission (again, IIRC) and I expect they know that, so again, not even remotely starting from a clean sheet, as the aliens would have to. Also, the guy that almost instantly said "That looks sadly random". HE gets the prize! He also made a very interesting argument FOR sending info, although that makes a BIG assumption, based on nothing, no data whatsoever.....except....the data point we have so far on no contact. The receiving society would have to have extreme FTL capability, if such is even possible, to act on it, anyway, so they probably don't have to be even a LOT more advanced than us to cause problems, but rather technologically VASTLY superior.

Making contact with aliens is not like shaking hands with a stranger. It's more like when Christopher Columbus met the Native Americans and killed them all, or when John Chau visited an isolated tribe and got speared to death.

Consider the dynamic between us and monkeys. Monkeys are very intelligent and similar to humans, but their technology lags behind ours. So, we cut down their homes and threaten their species with little regard for their lives, as we deem ourselves more important than them, and therefore our needs more important than theirs. In a situation in which we are visited by an advanced alien civilizations, we would be like monkeys to them. If they want to exterminate us and harness our planet's resources, very little stands in their way. There is a possibility that our interaction with aliens will be positive, but when we know so little about extraterrestrial life, it is idiotic to be sending out random signals across the universe for anyone to hear.

Some people have been on the ride for a long time and they begin to question: "Is this real, or is this just a ride?" And other people have remembered, and they come back to us, they say: "Hey, don't worry, don't be afraid, ever, because this is just a ride." ... and we kill those people.

Ha ha, "Shut him up. We have a lot invested in this ride. Shut him up. Look at my furrows of worry. Look at my big bank account and my family. This just has to be real." It's just a ride. But we always kill those good guys who try and tell us that, you ever notice that? And let the demons run amok. But it doesn't matter, because it's just a ride. And we can change it anytime we want. The eyes of fear want you to put bigger locks on your doors, buy guns, close yourself off. The eyes of love instead see all of us as ONE.

Here's what we can do to change the world, right now, to a better ride. If a civilization figured out the whole 23x79 thing, how could we guarantee they put it in the right order?  They might make the same image but going right to left rather than left to right, and therefore get a mirrored image.  They might arrange it horizontally rather than vertically. I mean just look around here on earth—the Latin alphabet writes left to right, top to bottom.  But Arabic is written right to left.  There are languages written top to bottom, and languages whose writing direction changes every line (called “boustrophedon”). We don’t know how they’d arrange the picture at all.  Moreover, this is presupposing they even HAVE writing at all! An alien civilization might not have needed writing in the first place, so they might not have ANY default order to arrange information.  Correct me if I’m wrong, but I’m pretty sure the Aricebo Message only works if the binary cells are arranged left to right, top to bottom.

Everyone who is more advanced than us, and that is within our radio bubble, already knows that we exist. And if they have the power to come here and destroy us (or do it from their home via a giant Stellaser or a Nicol-Dyson laser) they wouldn't need us to send out messages to find us (so, we really don't have to refrain from doing it - it's already too late). They'd already know that we exist and wouldn't be planet bound, specifically because they would be so much more powerful than we are today, and would primarily live in space (a thing we don't do yet). Also: We can not mask the waste heat of our technological activity. They can't do that either (that's a thermodynamics thing and has basically to do with the fact, that you only can reuse or repurpose a given amount of waste heat so much and then have to emit it away from you, or the system you exist in would overheat and destroy itself) and this problem gets worse the more technology you have; which means: The bigger you are, the better you are being seen from afar. If they exist, we should see them. Easily too. So, looking for them should reveal them very quickly and we'd have a very hard time, and honestly would have to be very ignorant and dense not to see them. We have looked, but as it seems: There is no other technology producing (spacefaring) civilization currently existing in our galaxy besides of us. At least none that we can see right now. And if civilizations emerge frequently, at least one should be within our detection range... but, no, there is nobody there. The galaxy, as it seems right now, is ours for the taking - nobody there to contest our claim on this same galaxy (being alone is a good thing in this scenario then). The same seems to be true for the rest of our supercluster (47 thousand galaxies are inside this cluster), every single one of them lacks the infrared signature of waste heat a spacefaring civilization would inevitably emit. Nobody there either. This is suspicious. My guess is: Since the universe is incredibly young, we are simply among the very first technological civilizations that ever emerged in the universe. Others exist, but they are rare and far between - too far away to see them, and we're too early on at the cosmic stage, that others simply haven't had enough time to have already emerged in great numbers within our detection range (the story will be very different in, say, 10 trillion years; I'd expect the cosmos - which got very dark by then, which would make it easier to see those others - to be brimming with spacefaring civilizations, some of them possibly even descendants from Earth). So, right now this seems to be the case:

There is nobody else out there (yet). And despite the popular humble opinions about our meaning to the universe: This rarity makes us very special.

I wouldn't be that pessimistic about coming into contact with an advanced alien civilization. Earth doesn't have any unique resources in large quantities that i know of that would be worth mining for extraterrestrial species and the chances of them wanting to colonise earth also seem rather slim to me, since they would be way more adapted to their own planet (just think of how much of a herculean task it would be for humans to terraform Mars). Even if they were forced to leave their own planet, it would just be highly unlikely statistically for them to choose our planet for colonisation out of the billions and billions of planets available. No, i think it's not that unlikely that they could have a genuine interest in establishing some form of communication with us. We are an interesting species after all: We send satellites into stabile orbits, that circulate the earth at unfathomable speeds and provide us with amazing technologies, like GPS or the internet, that are available to almost all members of our species as well. We are able to manipulate machines and even viruses on a nanometer level. We cure diseases and create vaccines. Sure, humanity is not perfect, but compared to every single other lifeform we discovered on earth so far, the things we do are nothing shy of incredible. I think an alien civilization just might be impressend enough to want to talk to us.

This logic that civilizations encountering less advanced ones leads to war therefore we should not communicate is not applicable in this situation. War breaks out for division of resources and conflicting ideologies. When all of space is your resource playground as it would be for a so advanced being, to pose threat from so far away, why would they waste their own resources to take ours. Earth doesn't have a lot of different resources from other planets out there, water (while frozen) is pretty common and oxygen can be extracted from it. The only exception is life, but even slavery isn't a rational fear since human labor relies on other life for energy and isn't that efficient. Surely a society so advanced would have systems or machines that are more efficiently powered. Witch leaves ideologies, that is more of a fear. A message from earth picked up by a supremacist society that seek to wipe out anything that's different. In my opinion that's the only risk.

I think one of the main problems with this is that we kinda assume that extraterrestrial life will be sort of like us. There is no guarantee that intelligent aliens will have the concept of domination, war, collaboration, etc. And there seems to be such a small chance that some alien race will actually be able to decode some complex message like the Arecibo message. Also, since it was sent 25,000 light years away, it will take 25,000 years to even reach its destination, after which likely no one on earth (if humans still exist then) will remember what we sent. Maybe our best bet is just sending tons of random signals in all different directions hoping that some aliens somewhere will find it as a point of interest, instead of trying to describe the entire human race in our messages. There's not really a point in trying to describe ourselves in a form only we understand. But then again, maybe, if there's some planet similar to Earth, organisms will evolve a similar way and reason like we do. Seems like a long shot though...

They also know, from the fact that both we and they still exist, that none of those groups thought preemptive attacks against intelligent life were good, either because (A) "only villains do that" or because (B) "no way we could get away with that." Therefore, they know that attacking us preemptively is likely not in their best interest, since it would tell third party A, if it is present, that the attacker is a villain, and third party B that preemptive attacks can be gotten away with in this region of space, if third party A is absent.

Message: Never gonna give you up, Never gonna let you down, Never gonna run around and desert you..

About the danger of being visited by a civilization more advanced than ours, I think the comparison with our past is not so much a good example. In those past events nobody was able to observe those technologically inferior people, so nobody among the more advanced people was able to know about them, discuss about what to do, and express opinions about that. The explorers who discovered those less advanced civilizations were mostly looking for more land to conquer, and they simply went on their route trying to find something valuable.
Now our entire species is unable to behave like that any more, just because we already know every landmass on our planet. We also know, at least within a certain resolution, the extension of the entire observable universe, and we're able to make at least some predictions of what could be out there in detail, compared to what we can directly observe. A species more advanced than ours would probably have a much more precise and detailed observation capability than ours, so they would have plenty of instruments and time to observe us from a distance, and then decide what to do with us. For such an advanced species Earth wouldn't be so valuable, as their technology would mostly certainly be capable of allow them to use resources from everywhere else. Our planet has much less resources, water included, than most of the other dead bodies in our solar system. A living planet like ours is valuable only to a species which is still unable to live outside of life suistaining planet. A spacefaring civilization wouldn't need that.
We're used to think of aliens sometimes as a conqueror species looking for more planets to colonize, but our point of view is comparable to a hunter-gatherer prehistoric human which can't live without natural growing plants and fruits, as he doesn't know about agriculture yet. For us is normal, and we don't need to migrate periodically to find more resources to live. An advanced spacefaring civilization wouldn't need a life sustaining planet to survive.
So, the only thing remaining to say is: why should a civilization like that reply to us? That depends on how they reason. What's their motivation to explore space? Do they have a free society, or are they some kind of "their-species supremacists"? Would they have any kind of moral ethic to make them think before interfering with our evolution?
We don't know. But I think it's very probable that a supremacist species wouldn't even think about us, and they wouldn't be interested in our planet just because it's too less valuable for them. So it could be very unlikely that any danger could come to us if they knew about our presence. In the worst case, maybe we would just see them pass, do their job ignoring us, leaving us with a very sad opinion of advanced lifeforms, maybe regretting the time when we were asking ourselves "are we alone?". We'll see. Soon, let's hope. In the meantime, we should focus doing our best to improve our society the best we can, taking for granted that we're on our own.

Idk if any of you care to read my random thoughts or if I'm even on to something. The physicist at the end of this video states that photons stay around forever, but I remember a Feynman diagram where if two photons collide they would create a gamma ray or more. I would suppose that there would have to be enough energy on behalf of one or both photons would have to have enough energy to be able to create such gamma rays. Yes gamma rays are photons in and of themselves but energy is really the key here to understanding how photons can take on new meanings if they are to collide. So let's just say there is a gravitational disturbance that sends off high frequency photons that collide with our radio wave photons. While the probability of one piece of our message getting hit by other photons is small over short distances, the longer the radio waves travel, the higher the probability of collision -- thus distorting our message. What if radio waves aren't the answer? I hypothesize that in order to send a message across the Galaxy, we would need to use neutrinos rather than photons. The reason being is that neutrinos rarely interact with anything. You might think that photons are small enough to not interact with other things, but the simple fact that our eyes and our transceivers can detect them is proof that photons can be captured and they can also be blocked because of things like mountains or even mere walls. Nevertheless--no matter the means of transcription--the longer the distance, the harder it is to decipher the message from noise.

Here are the problems with messaging and listening: Messaging is a loaded idea. You want us to control the receiver's understanding of the sender. You CANNOT use communication for communication's sake. You can't expect the receiver to answer. No advanced alien civilization would DARE to get in touch with us, if we don't control the context of our initial messages. As you don't engage a random wolf in the forest, an alien civilization has to decipher the intention behind the messaging. If we don't set down some rules, even the lack of context will be telling for another civilization. A message without self-awareness is a telling sign about the sender's current level. A message which just wants to establish contact, tells volumes about the sender's (then) current situation in their world.


If you wish to travel to Ghana, prior to your departure, would you establish everything you know about that country, based on one discussion you had with one random Ghanese person on Facebook?

Imagine yourself in the place of another advanced civilization. You know you will have to do your own research. You understand only yourself. You want to be careful. Even if the incoming message states paceful intentions, you cannot know who wrote it. Is the message a representative thing? Does it paint a picture of the society which sent it? Sure, you know some basic informations, but anybody on the sender's side can send these mathematical and visual guides. But who knows if the writer can be trusted? What if the messager made some errors? How would we know that they made some errors, when they tried to depict themselves? Does it represent its whole civilization, or just the messenger?
What errors, you ask? As we, humans are looking for human faces on mountains, on clouds, on our toasts, an alien might be looking for other kind of very specific things. If it is missing from our message, it can be percieved as an error.



Ask yourself, how should humanity approach a discovered alien civilisation! With care. We cannot establish contact, we have to observe first. Observation is key. An alien if it is observing us, might come to the conclusion, that they cannot conclude basic facts about us. Just imagine what has happened in 100 years on Earth. Who decides what represents our civilization? The few scientists, who couldn't initiate such scientific endeavours on their own? The politicans who give the green-lights for such missions? The dictators? The people who don't even care and they need wholesome Youtube celebrities to explain basic scientific facts to them? And what about those wars? Why are they killing each other? Do they welcome it? Do they know what does it mean to be human?

Some selected few want to get in touch with the whole universe, but they have no authority to define their own species. So they are just sending basic messages about their physiology and some selected fragments of something which could be deciphered as culture. But culture is not a static thing. Even if an alien can percieve culture, it doesn't give information about humanity. Don't get me wrong. Lot of informations we are sending out are interesting for other civilizations.



But we haven't yet sent a single important one. Humanity must find the questions first. Then they have to answer them. Then they have to put the answers on some constant things, radio waves, or monoliths in our Solar System (yet we have to assert our dominance here). And then, we have to send invitational messages for everybody to read those "license plates", monoliths. Don't come to us first. Read the "instructions on how to percieve us".
What would be there, on those monoliths of informations? The information which doesn't change. Which is "carved in stone".
Humanity has to commit itself to a narrative. A depiction, which is us. During thousands of years we have never looked into the mirror. We have to start adjusting ourselves, so others can understand as well. Because if we don't understand ourselves, if we dont't show a clear profile, an alien civilisation won't get in touch with us. With this listening and messaging we are just hoping that out there is another "human race", which doesn't define itself, but welcomes every fragment of information. We are still looking at clouds, and searching for familiar faces. We are not listening currently. We are an answering machine, on stand-by, which changes the welcoming speech every day.
SETI is a waste of money because aliens have been here for thousands of years. They speak to us using telepathy that's why we hear them in our own language.

I think the high points on your short list of solutions to the Fermi Paradox are (slightly rephrasing):
* Interstellar travel is really hard,
* Intelligent, technological life is rare, and
* Intelligent, technological life self-destructs.
and add to that, “the stars are really really far apart.”

We already know we can’t travel faster than light, unless Alcubierre warp drive proves feasible. Ether way, it will require unfathomably huge amounts of energy: Almost certainly far more than we could ever really afford.

Everybody seems to assume that technology keeps exponentiating indefinitely, but there’s no evidence to support that. We’ve seen humanity progress to high technology several times only to drop back into a new Dark Ages. I have no reason to expect humanity or any other intelligence to do any better!

What if the radio signals collide with another signal?

If aliens in one way or another are technologically behind or "below" us, then we may not get a response. If aliens are are technologically ahead or "above" us, then they may have decided to not "disturb" the sensitive humans and their "habitat" (much like we sometimes purposely avoid, or outright forbid, contact with certain uncontacted "primitive" tribes in the Amazonas or elsewhere). By the way, how can be certain that not some advanced species of ants aren't trying to communicate with US? Do we listen? No. (Stupid humans.)

Why WOULD aliens respond? There are a lot of assumptions inherent in these attempts to communicate:
1) That aliens care. 2) That aliens CAN respond. 3) That aliens WANT to respond. (In what way would that benefit their survival, in a scenario if limited resources?) 4) That aliens notice our messages. 5) That aliens would believe such signals are sent by other life.

the messages dont last forever, they will become distorted by gravitational lensing and expansion of the universe. Could also be interfered by particles of gas & dust and maybe dark matter (the latter being a speculation).

Gas & dust will distort the photons, slowing some down as they move through different mediums, blocking some or refracting. (obviously depending on the materials)

The message also becomes diluted with distance as photons move further away from each other - at least if use radio waves. A powerful laser might avoid this dilution, but eventually the resolution gets degraded and diluted. (the receiver to pick up every photon may need a receiver the size of a solar system - obviously depending on the distance away)

Just think of the pathetic minuscule light from the deep field Hubble image over extreme long exposures - and those "grains of light" are entire galaxies. There is no way to get the resolution to see lets say individual small stars from 10 billion light yrs away (although we do see quazars - but they are insanely huge power sources, larger that hundreds of millions of Suns).

But...energy inverse square law!!!
OMG! So much energy inverse square law is being ignored in this episode!
No first researcher guy, no one will ever receive Earth's early transmissions, or even current, or the ones from satellites, because... of the energy inverse square law! So we haven't "announced" our presence to anyone. We couldn't have! The signals are so diluted by the time they reach "someone", they have no freaking way in hell to isolate them from the CMB. It's like trying to see the light from a led in the middle of the sun. It something that will never be achieved, it's just how light works.
The alien messenger guy. Yes, you're using a somewhat more focused beam, but it will disperse eventually. Even the best lasers beams disperse. Yes, your message will go farther than Hitler's Olympic games opening speech, but will also be lost in the CMB before it reaches "anyone". So what you're actually doing, is like pointing a flashlight in the sky and expect aliens to see that, well they can't, again because of the...energy inverse square law.
Also, while his statements are true, nothing is ever lost, matter and energy wise, the do change forms. Those photons, though immortal, they do get converted into heat, by hitting a rock, or dust, or a planet or something, then scatter all over. Sure, try to decode a signal with half of it gone due to cosmic dust.
Lastly, I think we should find faster ways of communication, and transportation first, then try to communicate.
The way it is now, Steven Hawkins fear will never happen. When the hostile aliens see our message, and choose to attack for some reason, they will be late for a million years, or something due to light lag, and travel times. Who knows what might have happened by then? A ww3? A rogue asteroid? Or the human species colonizing the stars already.

This was really interesting to watch, and pretty sweet too. I think it proves a certain odd concept to explain, the fact that we aren't fully rational beings, and we are instead made out of rational and irrational parts.
Here we have a video about science and scientists in general and about space, people who are really smart and have a high amount of knowledge, we have Michael who throughout the entire video discusses these sciences, tries to find something in common with alien life, explains how scientists send messages about 'truths' to aliens, things like what we are and what we are made out of, our physical appearances, numbers, math, all of these very rational things.


But then at the end, when Michael has the chance to send a message out there into the universe, while other scientists would probably send more information about us and our cultures and what we are, Michael decided to send an image of himself and his grandmother, because she was a very important person in his life, and still is, considering the fact that she helped him be who he is now.
I think this is something that probably only us can experience, our irrational side, Michael is a very smart person and when faced with the opportunity to send a message out there, he did something out of love for an important person in his life. I'm unsure if alien life would be able to understand this concept, but I hope they do.

I expected the ending to convey a long, thought-out conclusion that incorporated all sorts of accessible insights into the world we’re on, free of emotional influence.

And then you brought it right back to what matters. It’s actually not about trying to make messages accessible. The best way to communicate is in the most human way possible. Using emotion, and love. That’s what makes us us.

My grandma was called Marjorie and I have always thought of her as a huge influence and inspiration. I’ve always wondered how we’d get on as adults (I was 15 when she left us) and if we would talk deeply about the universe.

This was so close to home and so helpful to watch. I think this serves as a reminder to value emotion just as much as logic. Thank you Michael :)

some science facts:

a 10 amino acids functional protein/enzyme/polypeptide

All of the theoretical responses and interpretations we assume other lifeforms could make are purely based on our own predispositions. How do we know if aliens would notice symmetry, since we are predisposed to recognizing it from human experiences? How do we know aliens would grasp mathematics, since our depiction of math is a human construct of our perception? Basing our outgoing messages purely on what we are familiar with in the most basic forms may not be the best philosophy in my opinion. This is the same as the theory that aliens would be conquerors because human history has proven that we do that, or that "all life" must be carbon based and need water to evolve. All of these examples lend to the self aggrandizing nature of human kind. If we're to truly reach out, we need to look at unorthodox methods of contact as well as our assumptions of other lifeforms.

I kind of want to send something following the KISS doctrine and make it nearly idiot-proof, but it would have specific requirements for how it's sent. Spread spectrum, with mathematically consistent intervals between the frequencies used, and to make it dum-dum simple that it's an artificial signal - it would just be counting in binary. Maybe hint that we use base ten by having it only count to 100. So it'd show math, that we know binary (computers), and base 10. Maybe the step between frequencies could have another layer of relevance like pi or some such. But the main thing is making it obvious that it's not background noise, and counting in binary would stick out like a sore thumb on something like a waterfall scan of adjacent frequencies. Pulsed signal would also allow more power to be put into pulses, and avoiding any encoding or more complicated carrier scheme than I/O also makes it a bit more basic.

Yeah it doesn't say much about humanity, or have a lot in technical, cultural, or even sentimental value. But I think it'd be a good "Hello" type message in that it'd give a framework for an equally obvious reply that could lead to more complex communication that would address those things later on.

I think this re-asks the question of if we OUGHT to be freely communicating into a realm that we are barely able to travel into. We are truly unprepared for Space. We have no defense of any kind for our planet — and indeed we are so poorly educated as a planet, we are destroying it ourselves. Do we really think we are ready to meet extraterrestrials? Let's see if we can understand our own oceans first - at least in the oceans we are pretty sure there are no hyper-evolved sentient lifeforms down there that might like to harvest us. Seems safer, a better first try.

In philosophy school we became sensitive to this truth: "Can and Should are not the same" — I personally think that long-distance communications aimed outside our own solar system or aside from a research vessel is substantially risky, given the proponents' own expectations: that life is out there which is at least as technologically capable as we are (ie, to be able to hear us and maybe respond). Again I say, look at us! Flip on the news in any country in the world, and you will see an endless reel of problems between communities/civilizations/groups/ideologies, etc.

What I immediately recognized from the randomized message was something in common with clapping out numbers.  Our limited range of beat and depth of working memory.  It implies a significant constraint on humans and human communication capabilities.  Something so basic to us that it is easily taken for granted, yet would be crucial to any alien understanding our communication patterns.   Individual message elements span a fraction of a heartbeat to a handful of heartbeats.  Individual unaided humans cannot process continuous complex messages much longer than a YouTube video.  No human would actually wait for you to clap out one million.  Any human attempting to clap out a million would give up at a similar low number.  Some aliens may have attention span for a billion or more claps.  Some other alien species may experience  lapses of attention (blink, yawn, sleep, death, generations, evolution) between clapping out 2 and 3.  The ever presence of a human heartbeat, or any clock is not mandatory for communication, but it is used in all common human communication except static images. Yet when he sent a static image, he imposed the need for a clock to see it.  With this message format, we are signaling our basic rate and attention span. What else are we signalling?  We speak binary? We are or are not sensitive to individual cycle count?  We are sensitive to differences in audio frequency within a narrow range?  How are we sending anything about our audio(pressure) sensitivity if the message is entirely electromagnetic?  We vibrate an electromagnetic carrier frequency modulated by audio frequencies representing a 2 bit code with absent word clock that must be split into an exactly sized grid to form a visual representation.  So for an alien to understand this message, they must understand at least the concept of 2 fundamentally different human senses(sight and sound), a code which not even all humans understand, all in a medium which our own bodies are completely insensitive to.  How about a more baseband experiment.  Could we recognize the plain English audio message "Hello" spoken at a reasonable volume if it took 1 hour from 'H' to 'o'?  1 minute?  How about if it took .01 second?  I'm reminded of biblical passages saying essentially 'one day is like a thousand years'.  If taken literally, that is among the longest standing templates we have for alien life.  It makes sense to craft messages that take that into account or look for such messages.  Does anyone see patterns in CMB?

But take this: why should we even advertise that there is a habitable (i.e. not totally scorched, etc.) planet inhabited by fairly mild creatures on (based on a rather simplistic nature of messages we have so far been sending out) a beginner level of technology? Considering that some resources or even lebensraum are always scarce, it seems to me freakingly naive to believe that "the other" will be peaceful and will generally leave us alone. Yes, aliens may and probably will have a different moral code than we (which could actually also be way more ruthless) but from history of all civilizations that ever existed on Earth I cannot think of a single one, which would not want to expand and subdue the others.
I do not much believe in precautonary principles (such as that we should kill our civilization by precautionary measures becouse maybe there is some warming that may possibly be caused by humans, no one knows for sure, but just in case), but in terms of potential galactic aliens sitting quietly with eyes and ears wide open sounds to me just reasonable. After all, first strike without a warning can well end the entire conflict.

something that confuses me about the arecibo message (and even the random message they were attempting to decipher) is how did they know its 23 across 73 down and not 73 across and 23 down


for example the arecibo message has alot of clear patterns in it, but if we were to interpret the table that was made as 73 across and 23 down instead of its correct order of 23 across and 73 down a lot of those patterns (if not all of the patterns) would be destroyed


edit: with a little more research i found this https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:AreciboMessageShifted.svg which is exactly what i mean
when your communicating with alien races i would imagine you would them to have to make as little assumptions as possible and having to assume they would interpret the image as 23 across and 73 down would leave a flaw with that message, this would mean that instead of using a 2 different primes to make this picture we would want to use the same prime (which would obviously produce a square) the closest prime square being 41 which has an area of 1681 which is only 8 bits larger than 23x73

saying that there's no pattern is as much pure interpretation as saying there is one. both ascribe value to something whose author, sentient or otherwise, is inherently estranged from it and whose potential intentional original values are dead: death of the author, and so on and so forth. just because it "looked" random, and indeed was from our frameworks, doesn't mean there isn't a message. much of cryptography looks random but only because we aren't privy to its patterns, and can be decrypted if you are. every search assumes other life functions as humans do—who's to say they even share our senses (if they exist at all)? Who's to say they share our models of mathematics (maybe they use something more like surreal numbers or a system which has never been used by humans)? It's highly arrogant to assume every lifeform will be like us.

I have three major issues with that whole "technologically advanced civilizations meeting less advanced ones doesn't end well for the latter" idea. One: it's not actually true. There's plenty of examples of cultures peacefully interacting throughout all of history. I'd argue moreso than not. Not only that, but it's mainly western colonialism that's been responsible for this phenomenon, and that's a cultural thing. The reason has nothing to do with the technological advancement. Two: this phenomenon when it has happened throughout history, has happened here on Earth, where resources have always been limited. When you're a superadvanced civilization that can cross the vastness of the cosmos, there isn't any resource on Earth that you can't easily get anywhere else, so there's no reason to be hostile toward its inhabitants. And three: this is all a very human-centric idea anyway. Aliens will most likely be nothing like us. They will not think like us or want the same things we want, so to expect them to act the way that we have acted throughout history isn't very logical.

I like the idea of communicating with other species and it would potentially be mutually beneficial to both species, but I'm with Stephen Hawking on this one. Every creature we're on this earth no matter how alien it is to us operates on the principle of cost and benefit. They won't contact us unless they're sure they can gain something, and they're unlikely to announce their presence unless they're sure we couldn't possibly pose a threat.
Humanity is not even close to being unified and I think the same is likely true of any other intelligent life out there. We could just be announcing our presence to the alien equivalent of a real estate developer who would just come here and "liquidate" everything into a form that is useful to them. Assuming that oxygen, water, and carbon are useful for other species it seems like they'd think of our planet as free space and resources.

Well, why are you assuming they have the same kind of mathematical intuitions hat we have? Not even we have the same idea of mathematics as everyone else, for example, think of the natural numbers, you know the counting numbers, now we could say that the natural begins with "1" and then "2" and then "3", but what about the number zero? Don´t we all start counting from nothing? Why not add it to our natural numbers´ class? You could argue, perhaps, that for a long time we didn´t have the idea of zero, therefore it is not "natural", but then you are saying that the natural numbers are the same as something else, that is, the positive integers, why, then, think of "natural" numbers if we have a more precise description fo what it is? Also, if "natural" means "intuitive", the number googolplex ISN´T intuitive but it is a counting number, should we exclude all such "unintuitive" numbers from the naturals? At which point should we say that a given number is not "intuitive" and, therefore, not natural? The point is that if we don´t have a common, intuitive notion fo what such a basic concept such as "natural numbers" is, then what hope do we have that aliens will share those conceptions about it?

Furthermore, the "technologically advanced" argument is a fallacious projection of our own mentality, there´s no reason, beyond human nature that is, that makes it necessary for a technologically superior civilization to subjugate an inferior one. They may be very well a civilization that would protect us or, even, have rules for non-interference with non-FTL races, who knows? But we cannot assume they will react in such an anthropocentric way to first contact.

Given the far from complete information we have it's most likely that we are functionally alone in the universe so one might say attempting to contact 'aliens' is harmless folly, but:
-What if we are not alone?
-What if there intelligences out there capable of picking up our messages?
Well, if 'they' are on a similar level to us any attempt to make contact is harmless folly because over the distances involved by the time 'they' receive our message we will probably be long gone let alone the time required to get any reply. Communication if impossible.
-But it's still worth making the effort because even if communication is impossible it would be 'good' to know we are not alone so we need to hope 'everyone' is at least happy to say "hello".
It's impossible to know how society would react to proof that there's other intelligent life. What if that knowledge precipitates an existential dread that results in the breakdown of our civilisation or indeed that our attempt at communication destroys the recipient of our message?
-That's incredibly unlikely and besides we, and maybe others out there, are 'accidentally' transmitting already so what does a bit more communication matter?
Unlikely as such a scenario might be this is a Pandora's box issue. Once out of the box the knowledge can't be put back in. Is sending a message worth the risk of destroying another civilisation? Yes, we are already listening but is 'living' in space is like walking through an unknown jungle; you may come across something interesting or something dangerous that's how life is. But actively looking for a Lion could be considered risky and willingly putting your head in it's mouth would be considered foolhardy by most. Attempting to put another's head in a Lion's mouth might be considered attempted murder - morally dubious and what if a society 'out there' takes that view?
So far that's the potential risks of the best case scenario: One where the civilisations involved must learn to deal with the knowledge that 'we are not alone' for good or for ill. But what if 'we' contact 'someone' who is far more advanced than us? Given how old the universe is if there are people 'out there' there's a decent chance 'they' are. That risks them coming to visit.
-We could learn so much from contact from a more advanced civilisation
True, but that isn't going to happen. Even if 'they' arrived with entirely benevolent intent (not necessarily true) our own history has shown that more primitive groups never survive contact with more highly developed societies no-matter the intent of that developed society. Worse, if 'they' are as advanced to us as 'we' are to other creatures on this planet malicious or benevolent intent won't come in to it. We will die simply because we are beneath any such considerations.
-Now you're just anthropomorphizing!
Maybe but the basic principles of physics, and therefore biology apply just as well elsewhere in the universe as they do here. No matter how 'alien' any aliens may be they will have gotten to their position on their planet the same way we did: Natural selection, or to put it another way by climbing over the corpses of billions of their forebears and current rivals for resources. In short it is entirely reasonable to assume that however different 'they' may be 'they' will have the same fundamental motivations a behaviors as us.
-Be we are intelligent, we don't obey our instincts?
Really? If H. Sapiens spent the last 7M years adapting to the role of hunter-gatherer and top predator, and the last 200K years getting really good at to the point where we are the dominant large life form on this planet how far do you think our fundamental wiring will have changed in the last 10K (more like 200) years? Yep, not at all. We live in an industrial world of our own making and the irony is we are supremely poorly adapted to that world - I would submit that nearly all the world's problems are the result of us behaving as our wiring dictates in a world where said wiring is no longer suitable. We have the awareness to be able to see what we are doing and maybe even what behavioral changes would be best for current circumstances but we have no ability to anything about it. Long tangent's aside 'intelligent aliens' will have exactly the same issues and those issues won't be good for us should we meet.
-Ok, ok. But it would still be comforting to know we aren't alone.
Really? I won't go in to the whole thing but there is the concept of 'great filters'. The upshot is that if we find life out there that spells bad news for our prospects down here, and those prospects get dramatically worse the more advanced that life is - appallingly bad if we were to find a beacon from a dead alien civilisation. We may not be able to do anything about whatever great filters there may be but sometimes ignorance is bliss.

My question is related to distance, signal to noise ratio and power. I am curious exactly how far away the message is actually able to be understood. As signals get further away from the transmission point the signal becomes more attenuated.

So at some point the signal becomes too weak and spread out to be put back together. So it is incorrect to say that the message will travel forever.

So my question is just exactly how far will your message will travel before becoming unintelligible noise? Will it actually have the potential ability to even reach our nearest star 4 light years away? Where did you point your message too? How many potential stars would it reach?

How much of that little transmitter signal got absorbed just trying to get through our atmosphere?

His justification about why it's ok to send signals despite it being risky is quite dumb IMO. He has incredibly specific and unlikely example, which is that maybe the aliens have already seen us and are just waiting to hear that we want to talk. If they have picked up radio signals, then they have picked up everything. Every electromagnetic form of radiation we are emitting is simply too weak to reach very far from Earth, so despite the fact that we have been emitting signals for as long as we have had radio, only aliens who are very very close will ever pick up those signals. If they are that close then they've picked up everything and should have seen all our probes and thus figured out that we do want to talk. It sounds like bullshit to me, and I think it's a horrible justification for continuing to signal to possible ETs.


"What if they're at the same place as us? We could exchange the recipe for fusion..." I think again a bad argument. The Fermi Paradox suggests we should see a lot of life because there has been so much time for it to develop, thus is a high chance that any ET we do run into may in fact have significantly better tech than us. We aren't going extinct right now, I think humans can figure out our problems well enough on our own(hopefully) so we do not need to run the massive risk of being destroyed by a more advanced civilisation. I am incredibly curious about what's out there, but in my opinion we should only make contact with ETs if we find them and have the chance to look into them before making that decision. Giving a possibly malicious civilisation the upper hand in choosing how that interaction happens (i.e. if they find us without us knowing) is a really bad idea.

I have been watching vsauce for years and in that time I have come to find a lot of respect and even admiration for Michael and what he has been doing. I often think that he has been making the best use of the technological age to inform, educate, and inspire millions of people around the world to find passion in an intricate understanding of every part of the human experience. I also think that if the billions of views that have gone to what I believe to be just silly or meaningless videos had gone to Michael's videos this world would be a better place. I am for the most part a cold, bitter, and analytical individual who finds disdain in some aspects of the human experience. But, those things are ultimately a part of who "WE" are. Some of us find joy where most find nothing at all. We are all made up of the exact same stuff and yet We can perceive, think, talk, and act so fundamentally different from each other that we form divides between us where there were none to begin with. I believe that this ability is our greatest strength and our greatest weakness all at once. While I agree to an extent that it could be dangerous to give another civilization out there some where a detailed understanding of our weaknesses as a civilization, I believe we should. The search for truth is a defining attribute of who we are, and we should be open and truthful to all those around us.

But I am ranting and have strayed away from my original point, Michael, I believe in a single image you have sent the greatest thing ever sent to space. A true depiction of "US", not the fake, seemingly unnatural images on the voyager golden discs, but a genuine human experience that I believe is our greatest value. why would another civilization cross the vast void of space, giving up in some cases entire life times, just to come talk to some awkward almost creepy nerds about math. It is only the human experience as a whole and in all it's complexity, that would ever make such a voyage worth undertaking. I only wish you could have sent the story behind the image along side it because damn it, it made me cry. I am no alien but this made we want to venture into the unknown just so I could give you a hug. Maybe some day that image will make it's way back home among a litany of others and be a small part of why it was worth it.

And as always...thanks for uploading.

Okay so let’s imagine that in 13 billion or so years that we’ve decided the universe has existed, there’s been a certain amount of time that was required for the conditions of life to be fulfilled.. the longest of these was creating the heavy elements responsible for the more intense processes involved in life existing.. so considering that there must be entire life cycles of Star systems before life is even possible in any given region of space we could say that for our said region it would be logical if life began spreading at a similar pace. So assuming that another population or species has discovered science to a level equivalent to our own, it would be limited by the transmission speed which is the limit for all physical things, the speed of light. So considering that our galaxy the Milky Way is approximately 100,000 light years across, we probably won’t be seeing any signs from our neighbors for another several eons at the least, unless life is EXTREMELY common and turns out to be all over the place in which case it is likely on a planet within a relatively short span of distance

However, I will say that only recently does humankind know binary is a great way to communicate. I was 15 when I saw Carl Sagan's Cosmos: a Personal Journey . Only then, in 1979, did I learn that mathematics and the binary system would be a great way to communicate to ETs. So I think that just before the age of personal computers did the general public think that binary could be used ideally to communicate with ETs. That's less than a half century ago.

So while humankind has advanced by leaps and bounds, we can't assume everybody knows that binary is possibly the best way to communicate. And ETs might even think tl;dr, because they might get the idea from 2 words.

This is my concern: What if other intelligent beings have invented radios and other technology that receives/transmits signals in a way that uses the data differently? Our message might arrive as garbled nonsense for them, even if it were something "universal", if the information isn't received correctly it's as good as sending random noise. Hell, what if the random noise we hear is actually other civilizations?

Regarding more advanced societies meeting less advanced... this gets less destructive to more morally advanced we become. These days we're even disinfecting spacecraft before sending them out. I don't think a more advanced civilisation would stomp all over a less advanced civilisation, especially if both are capable of leaving their homeworld. However, I do think the distances between advanced spacefaring civilisations is too vast for such civilisations to actually meet.

I greatly dislike the "why haven't we heard from aliens" argument. Let's say, for the sake of argument, there's an identically advanced civilization on the other side of the Milky Way, equidistant from the center. How long would it take a message from them to arrive here? We're roughly 25,000 light years from the center of the galaxy, so it'd take 50,000 years for us to receive their message. If they were to send the message today we'd not receive it until the year 52019 or so. That's the problem with the search for extrasolar life. And from stars outside of our galaxy? A message from Andromeda would take over 2.5 million years to reach us. Most likely the whole reason we've not found anyone is because they're just too damn far away for current tech to find. It's almost like how Europe and Asia were doing their thing for a few thousand years before they found people living in North America. Or even knew North America existed. Light speed is just way too slow for these kinds of distances.


As for people knowing we're here, the first radio transmission was sent in 1900. 119 years ago. The furthest you'd be able to detect that is 119 light years from Earth. In terms of cosmic distances, that's nothing. Having another civilization so close to us would mean that either it's an incredible stroke of luck, or that life is so common across the galaxy (or universe) that everyone is in everyone else's back yard. In addition, in order for someone to have picked up our first radio transmission and sent a signal back that we'd receive today, they'd have to be closer than 60 ly.

Seems as if the issue with sending an EM signal across the stars is in-transit deterioration. Sure, you can detect light from a distant sun all the way from another galaxy, but a meaningful signal isn't just EM radiation -- it's an intelligible pattern encoded into that radiation. If quantum randomness decays the signal at unpredictable points along the data stream, the signal would gradually lose its meaningful pattern while filling in the gaps with background noise. After a certain astronomically large distance, you may still receive a signal, but "decoding" it would surely become a fool's errand at some point. So I don't think we really need to worry about what distant alien civilizations think of I Love Lucy or the Andy Griffith Show, unless of course they are already a star faring species that just happens by pure chance to be cruising fairly close to our system when they intercept it.


If you really wanted to send a message out proactively, what you do is put a fairly large spacecraft out far enough that it can eclipse the Sun from the viewpoint of some distant observer, then do so in a regular, patterned fashion. It would be a narrow cast rather than broadcast signal, so you'd have to choose your destination targets carefully. The trajectory mathematics would require fairly high levels of astronomical precision to actually work, and unlike a radio signal, the frequency would have to be very slow, not only to maximize signal lifetime but also because it takes time to maneuver a spacecraft into and out of shadowing position. Aaaand... the observer would definitely know where the signal was coming from. So, there's still the "should we" question involved.

I love that optimism, but the distances would be so unimaginably far I wonder if any dialogue would be feasible. One of the probable reasons for the Fermi Paradox is that they are just very far away. Let's assume they're relatively close, like... 100 LY. Say we receive trace signals in 2020, and right away we send out a message. It would take 100 years for it to reach them, then another 100 years for their answer to reach us. That's 200 years of wait time, for a relatively close civilization, just to start a conversation.

Imagine, in 200 years we'll probably have already figured out fusion power.

Rest Easy Margie Stevens!

The difference between the I Love Lucy transmissions and intentional interstellar communications is that the former are like shining a flashlight into the dark. The later is more like beaming a laser out onto a target. Even if TV and radio transmissions were quite powerful, they will quickly fade into the background noise of the cosmos as they spread out. A tightly focused signal has a much better chance of remaining intact and travelling much further. So... I would say, it's still a valid concern, whether or not to alter other civilizations to our presence. To say "Oh it's fine, they probably already know we're here." seems like a poor argument.

In fact, that's a very likely explanation for the Fermi Paradox. Other civilizations may produce lots of "radio noise", but as their technology has gotten better and better, the amount of signals that are lost to noise stays small (even as the complexity of their civilizations increase). And, perhaps, they are just far away enough that this radio noise fades into the background before it reaches us. We may have to wait until we can build massive radio-dishes on the surface of the moon before we can truly say "We can determine with great certainty that the area of space within 10,000 lightyears around us has or does not have intelligent alien life."

one of these is an interesting experiment and the other is a pointless waste of time.
